Cognate with Scots abide (â€œto abide, remainâ€), Middle High German erbÄ«ten (â€œto await, expectâ€), Gothic ğŒ¿ğƒğŒ±ğŒ´ğŒ¹ğŒ³ğŒ°ğŒ½ (usbeidan, â€œto expect, await, have patienceâ€). The sense of pay for is due to influence from aby.

verbs.description: abide (third-person singular simple present abides, present participle abiding, simple past abode or abided, past participle abode or abided or (rare) abidden)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To endure without yielding; to withstand. [from mid-12th c.]
examples: Synonyms: hold on, resist, persevere; see also Thesaurus:persevere
The old oak tree abides the wind endlessly.
Synonyms: brook, put up with, tolerate; see also Thesaurus:tolerate
"I never could abide shoemakers," said an old servant,â€”and it ended in her marrying one.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pay for; to stand the consequences of. [from late 16th c.]
Used in a phrasal verb: abide by (â€œto accept and act in accordance withâ€).
examples: The new teacher was strict and the students did not want to abide by his rules.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To wait in expectation. [mid-12thâ€“mid-17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: hold on, stay; see also Thesaurus:wait

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To pause; to delay. [from ca. 1150â€”1350 to mid-17th c.]
(intransitive, archaic, Scotland) To stay; to continue in a place; to remain stable or fixed in some state or condition; to be left. [from ca. 1150â€”1350]
(intransitive, archaic) To have one's abode. [from ca. 1350â€”1470]
examples: Synonyms: dwell, live, reside; see also Thesaurus:reside

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To endure; to remain; to last. [from ca. 1350â€”1470]
(transitive, archaic) To stand ready for; to await for someone; watch for. [from early 12th c.]
examples: Synonyms: await, wait for; see also Thesaurus:wait for

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To endure or undergo a hard trial or a task; to stand up under. [from ca. 1150â€”1350 to early 18th c.]
(transitive, archaic) To await submissively; accept without question; submit to. [from ca. 1350â€”1470]
